The expression "'''10,000 Buddhas'''" is used in the names of these notable Buddhist sites: *[[City of Ten Thousand Buddhas]], in [[Ukiah, California]] *[[Kek Lok Si]] Temple, called the "Pagoda of the Ten-Thousand Buddhas", in [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]] *[[Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery]], in [[Hong Kong]] *[[Yulin Caves]], called the "Ten Thousand Buddhas Caves", in [[Anxi County]], [[Gansu Province]], [[China]] *[[Zhenfeng Pagoda]], called the "Ten-thousand Buddhas", in [[Anqing]], [[Anhui Province]], [[China]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Christian Eschatology}} American Christian radio host [[Harold Camping]] stated that the [[Rapture]] and [[Last Judgment|Judgment Day]] would take place on May 21, 2011,<ref>{{cite news |title=A Conversation With Harold Camping, Prophesier of Judgment Day |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/05/a_conversation_with_harold_cam.html |newspaper=New York Magazine |date=May 11, 2011 |accessdate=October 13, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Harold Camping is at the heart of a mediapocalypse |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/21/local/la-me-rapture-20110521 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=May 21, 2011 |accessdate=October 13, 2011 |first=Christopher |last=Goffard}}</ref> and that the end of the world would take place five months later on October 21, 2011, based on adding the 153 fish of John 20 to May 21.<ref>http://www.lamblion.us/2011/03/harold-camping-end-time-scenario.html</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url = http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/may21/index.html |title = May 21, 2011 – Judgment Day!; October 21, 2011 – The End of the World |publisher = Ebiblefellowship.com |date = May 21, 1988 |accessdate =November 29, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101028050127/http://ebiblefellowship.com/may21/index.html| archivedate= October 28, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The Rapture, as indicated in 1 Thessalonians 4:17 (''harpagēsometha'' = we shall be raptured / taken up, "rapture" derivable from the Latin translation ''rapiemur'') is the taking up of believers to a meeting in the air with the Lord Jesus, but for Camping the rapture was also associated with the End of the World.<ref>http://www.lamblion.us/2011/03/harold-camping-end-time-scenario.html</ref>
Camping, who was then president of the [[Family Radio]] Christian network, claimed the Bible as his source and said May 21 would be the date of the Rapture and the day of judgment "beyond the shadow of a doubt".<ref>{{cite news |title = End of Days in May? Believers enter final stretch |url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40885541/m/videos/ |newspaper = Associated Press, cited at MSNBC |date = January 23, 2011 |accessdate =May 9, 2011}}</ref> Camping suggested that it would occur at 6 pm local time, with the Rapture sweeping the globe time zone by time zone,<ref name=Amira /><ref>[http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/scocca/archive/2011/05/16/countdown-to-armageddon-maybe-the-world-will-end-friday-night-or-sunday-morning.aspx Scocca : Countdown to Armageddon: Maybe the World Will End Friday Night (or Sunday Morning)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> while some of his supporters claimed that around 200 million people (approximately 3% of the world's population) would be 'raptured'.<ref name=JudgmentDay /> Camping had previously claimed that the Rapture would occur in September 1994.
The vast majority of Christian groups, including most Protestant and Catholic believers, did not accept Camping's predictions;<ref>{{cite web |url = http://relijournal.com/christianity/may-21st-the-new-christian-doomsday/ |title = May 21st, The New Christian Doomsday |publisher = ReliJournal |date = May 6, 2011 |accessdate =May 11, 2011}}</ref> some explicitly rejected them,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.gracevalley.org/Letter_to_Harold_Camping_True_Prophet_Or_False.pdf |title = Letter to Harold Camping (Family Radio) True Prophet or False? |publisher = |accessdate = May 10, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101222183254/http://gracevalley.org/Letter_to_Harold_Camping_True_Prophet_Or_False.pdf |archive-date = December 22, 2010 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/billboards-marking-jesus-return-in-may-misguided-says-nt-scholar-48083/ |title = Billboards Marking Jesus' Return in May 'Misguided,' Says NT Scholar |publisher = |accessdate =May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-faith/post/end-times-theology-an-insiders-guide/2011/05/10/AFCsXAiG_blog.html |title = End times theology: an insider's guide |date = May 10, 2011|work = The Washington Post|accessdate =May 10, 2011 |first=Brian D. |last=McLaren | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120111102343/http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-faith/post/end-times-theology-an-insiders-guide/2011/05/10/AFCsXAiG_blog.html | archive-date = January 11, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/catholic-scholar-dismantles-may-21-judgment-day-claims/ |title = Catholic scholar dismantles May 21 Judgment Day claims |author = Marianne Medlin |date = May 20, 2011 |publisher = Catholic News Agency |accessdate =May 20, 2011}}</ref> citing Bible passages including the words of Jesus stating "about that day or hour no one knows" (Matthew 24:36). An interview with a group of church leaders noted that all of them had scheduled church services as usual for Sunday, May 22.<ref>[http://www.nbc29.com/story/14665758/church-leaders-across-denominations-reflect-on-the-end-of-days ''Church Leaders Across Denominations Reflect on Camping's Prediction''] NBC29, May 17, 2011. Retrieved May 18, 2011.</ref>
Following the failure of the prediction, media attention shifted to the response from Camping and his followers. On May 23, Camping stated that May 21 had been a "spiritual" day of judgment, and that the physical Rapture would occur on October 21, 2011, simultaneously with the destruction of the universe by God.<ref name = "G&M">[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/americas/radio-host-says-rapture-actually-coming-in-october/article2032209/ Radio host says Rapture actually coming in October] – ''Globe and Mail''. May 23, 2011. Retrieved May 23, 2011.</ref><ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13516796 | work=BBC News | title=Rapture: Harold Camping issues new apocalypse date | date=24 May 2011 | accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref> However, on October 16, Camping admitted to an interviewer that he did not know when the end would come,<ref name="retire">{{cite news |title=Harold Camping Exclusive: Family Radio Founder Retires; Doomsday 'Prophet' No Longer Able to Work |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/harold-camping-exclusive-family-radio-founder-retires-doomsday-prophet-no-longer-able-to-work-59222/ |newspaper=The Christian Post |date=October 24, 2011 |accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> and made no public comment after October 21 passed without his predicted apocalypse.<ref name=WorldSurvives>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2052114/You-come-Harold-Doomsday-prophet-remains-hiding-world-survives-Rapture--AGAIN.html?ito=feeds-newsxml "Doomsday prophet remains in hiding"]. ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', October 22, 2011</ref>
In March 2012, Camping "humbly acknowledged" in a letter to Family Radio listeners that he had been mistaken, that the attempt to predict a date was "sinful", and that critics had been right in pointing to the scriptural text "of that day and hour knoweth no man". He added that he was searching the Bible "even more fervently [...] not to find dates, but to be more faithful in our understanding."<ref>[http://charismanews.com/us/32958-harold-camping-admits-rapture-prediction-was-sinful-statement Letter from Harold Camping to the "Family Radio Family"], reproduced at ''Charisma News,'' March 7, 2012</ref>
==Predictions==
===Camping's predictions=== * The Rapture would occur on May 21, 2011.<ref name="sfgate faq">{{cite news |title = The end-of-the-world FAQ sheet |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/hottopics/detail?entry_id=89183 |newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle | first=Mike |last=Moffitt |date=May 17, 2011}}</ref> * Massive earthquakes (greater in magnitude than the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Japanese earthquake]]) would happen across the world at 6 pm local time.<ref name=Amira>{{cite news |last = Amira |first = Dan |title = A Conversation With Harold Camping, Prophesier of Judgment Day |url = http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/05/a_conversation_with_harold_cam.html |accessdate =May 21, 2011 |newspaper = [[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date = May 11, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110518220328/http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/05/a_conversation_with_harold_cam.html| archivedate= May 18, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> * The end of the world would take place five months later on October 21, 2011.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
===Related predictions by others=== * Approximately 3% of the world's population would be called to [[heaven]].<ref name="sfgate faq"/> * Earthquakes would begin on May 21 on [[Kiritimati]] (Christmas Island), [[Kiribati]] at 6 pm LINT (0400 UTC).<ref name="sfgate faq" /><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10724132 |title = Apocalypse soon, says US preacher |author = Frances Morton |date = May 8, 2011 |work = The New Zealand Herald|accessdate =May 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/149512/20110521/doomsday-may-21-new-zealand-first-to-get-earthquake-says-camping.htm |title = New Zealand first to get Earthquake, says Camping |accessdate =May 20, 2011}}</ref> * Citing [[Book of Jeremiah|Jeremiah]] 25:32, earthquakes would continue "as the sun advances" with New York, United States, to be affected at approximately 6 pm EDT (2200 UTC). Some earthquakes will trigger giant [[Tsunamis]] 100 times taller than the average [[megatsunami ]] which they claim is 100 meters (330 feet) tall . The waves will go as far inland as [[Colorado]].<ref name="sfgate faq" />
===Camping's revised prediction=== * On May 23, 2011, Harold Camping stated that May 21 had been a "spiritual" Judgment Day and that the Rapture would occur on October 21, 2011, together with the destruction of the world.<ref>Garance Burke, "Radio host says Rapture actually coming in October," Associated Press, May 23, 2011, at {{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110524/ap_on_re_us/us_apocalypse_saturday |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525064617/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110524/ap_on_re_us/us_apocalypse_saturday |archivedate=May 25, 2011 |df=mdy }}.</ref><ref name="what happened">{{cite web|url=http://www.familyradio.com/x/whathappened.html |title=What happened on May 21? |publisher=Family Radio |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811120223/http://www.familyradio.com/x/whathappened.html |archivedate=August 11, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref> In a web posting titled "What happened on May 21?", Family Radio explained "Thus we can be sure that the whole world, with the exception of those who are presently saved (the elect), are under the judgment of God, and will be annihilated together with the whole physical world on October 21, 2011, on the last day of the present five months period."<ref name = "what happened" />
==Rationale== {{Quote box |title = |quote = "I know it's absolutely true, because the Bible is always absolutely true."<ref name="Daily Mail report"/> |source = <center>— [[Harold Camping]], president, [[Family Radio]], speaking prior to May 21, 2011</center> |align = right |width = 23% |border = |fontsize = |bgcolor = |style = |title_bg = |title_fnt = |tstyle = |qalign = center |qstyle = |quoted = |salign = |sstyle = }}
Camping presented several arguments labeled "[[numerology|numerological]]" by the mainstream media,<ref name="party">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43082513/ns/us_news-life/?GT1=43001 ''End of the world? How about a party instead?''], Associated Press, quoted at MSNBC, May 18, 2011. Retrieved May 19, 2011</ref> which he considered biblical proofs, in favor of the May 21 end time. A civil engineer by training, Camping stated he had attempted to work out mathematically-based prophecies in the Bible for decades. In an interview with the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' he explained "... I was an engineer, I was very interested in the numbers. I'd wonder, 'Why did God put this number in, or that number in?' It was not a question of unbelief, it was a question of, 'There must be a reason for it.'"<ref name="SFGATE Interview">{{cite news |url = http://articles.sfgate.com/2010-01-01/bay-area/17466332_1_east-bay-bay-area-first-time-camping/2 |title = Biblical scholar's date for rapture: May 21, 2011 |last = Berton |first = Justin |date = January 1, 2010 |work = San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate = March 12, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629044050/http://articles.sfgate.com/2010-01-01/bay-area/17466332_1_east-bay-bay-area-first-time-camping/2 |archive-date = June 29, 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
In 1970, Camping dated the [[Flood myth|Great Flood]] to 4990 BC.<ref name=BCH>{{cite journal |last = Camping |first = Harold |title = The Biblical Calendar of History |journal = [[American Scientific Affiliation|Journal of the American Scientific Affiliation]] |year = 1970 |volume = 22 |url = http://www.asa3.org/ASA/PSCF/1970/JASA9-70Camping.html |accessdate =May 16, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110607021007/http://www.asa3.org/ASA/PSCF/1970/JASA9-70Camping.html| archivedate= June 7, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Using this date, taking the statement in Genesis 7:4 ("Seven days from now I will send rain on the earth") to be a prediction of the end of the world, and combining it with [[2 Peter]] 3:8 ("With the Lord a day is as a thousand years, and a thousand years are as a day"), Camping concluded that the end of the world would occur in 2011, 7000 years from 4990 BC.<ref name=JudgmentDay>{{cite web |title = Judgment Day |url = http://www.familyradio.com/graphical/literature/judgment/judgment.html |publisher = [[Family Radio]] |accessdate = May 16, 2011 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110608095448/http://www.familyradio.com/graphical/literature/judgment/judgment.html |archivedate = June 8, 2011 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Camping takes the 17th day of the second month mentioned in Genesis 7:11 to be May 21, and hence predicts the Rapture to occur on this date.<ref name=JudgmentDay />
Another argument<ref>{{cite web |last = Camping |first = Harold |title = We Are Almost There! |url = http://www.familyradio.com/graphical/literature/waat/waat.pdf |publisher = Family Stations, Inc |pages = 44–63 |date = August 2010 |access-date = May 18, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110523175211/http://www.familyradio.com/graphical/literature/waat/waat.pdf |archive-date = May 23, 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref> that Camping used in favor of the May 21 date is as follows:
# The number five equals "atonement", the number ten equals "completeness", and the number seventeen equals "heaven". # The number of days (as calculated below) between April 1, 33 AD, and May 21, 2011 AD, is 722,500. ## Christ is believed by Camping to have hung on the cross on April 1, 33 AD. The time between April 1, 33 AD, and April 1, 2011, is 1,978 years. ## If 1,978 is multiplied by 365.2422 days (the number of days in a [[Solar year|solar]], as distinct from [[Lunar year|lunar]], year), the result is 722,449. ## The time between April 1 and May 21 is 51 days. ## 51 added to 722,449 is 722,500. # (5 × 10 × 17)<sup>2</sup> or (atonement × completeness × heaven)<sup>2</sup> also equals 722,500.
Camping said that 5 × 10 × 17 is telling us a "story from the time Christ made payment for our sins until we're completely saved."<ref name="SFGATE Interview" />
Camping was not precise about the timing of the event, saying that "maybe" we can know the hour.<ref name = "Slate">[http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/scocca/archive/2011/05/16/countdown-to-armageddon-maybe-the-world-will-end-friday-night-or-sunday-morning.aspx ''Countdown to Armageddon: Maybe the World Will End Friday Night (or Sunday Morning),''] Slate, May 7, 2011. Retrieved May 17, 2011</ref> He has suggested that "days" in the Bible refer to daylight hours particularly.<ref name = "Slate" /> Another account said the "great earthquake" which signals the start of the Rapture would "start in the [[Pacific Rim]] at around the 6 pm local time hour, in each time zone."<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2011/05/07/136053462/is-the-end-nigh-well-know-soon-enough ''Is The End Nigh? We'll Know Soon Enough''], [[NPR]], May 7, 2011. Retrieved May 17, 2011</ref>
In Camping's book ''1994?'', self-published in 1992, he predicted that the End Times would come in September 1994 (variously reported as September 4<ref name="Daily Mail report">{{cite news |url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1363837/Doomsday-campers-Project-Caravan-say-world-end-May-21.html |title = Doomsday campers Project Caravan say the world will end May 21 |date = March 8, 2011 |work=Daily Mail |location=London |accessdate =March 11, 2011 | archiveurl= https://archive.is/20110310161640/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1363837/Doomsday-campers-Project-Caravan-say-world-end-May-21.html| archivedate= March 10, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> or September 6<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.salon.com/news/religion/index.html?story=/politics/war_room/2011/05/15/may_21_end_of_world |title = The end of the world is here ... again |author = David S. Reynolds |publisher = Salon.com |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref>). When the Rapture failed to occur on the appointed day, Camping said he had made a mathematical error.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/03/national/main7208264.shtml |title = Apocalypse Soon: Christian Movement Says May 21, 2011 |publisher = CBS News |date = January 3, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref>
==Criticism== [[File:Doomsdayer in New York.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A demonstrator at [[Radio City Music Hall]].]] Camping's rapture prediction, along with some of his other teachings and beliefs, sparked controversy in the Christian and secular Western worlds. His critics often quoted Bible verses (such as {{Bibleverse||Matthew|24:36|KJV}}) they interpret as saying that the date of the end will never be known by anyone but [[God the Father|God]] until it actually happens. However, Camping and his followers responded that this principle only applied during the "church age" or pre-[[Tribulation]] period and did not apply to the present day, citing other verses (such as {{Bibleverse|1|Thessalonians|5:1–5:5|KJV}}) in their rebuttal.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.familyradio.com/graphical/literature/nomanknows/nomanknows.html |title = No Man Knows The Day Or The Hour? |publisher = Familyradio.com |accessdate =November 29, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101211021108/http://www.familyradio.com/graphical/literature/nomanknows/nomanknows.html| archivedate= December 11, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In a 2001 pamphlet, Camping asserted that believers should "flee the church", resigning from any church they belong to, because the "Church Age" is over and the "[[Great Tribulation]]" has begun.<ref name = "CT">{{cite web |url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2002/may21/12.21.html |title = New Dispensation? Camping: 'Leave Church' |first = Mark |last = Kellner |date = May 21, 2002 |publisher = Christianity Today |accessdate =April 6, 2011 }}</ref> This assertion was controversial<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.christiancourier.com/articles/582-harold-campings-new-revelation-leave-the-church |last = Jackson |first = Wayne |title = Harold Camping's New Revelation: "Leave the Church!" |publisher = Christian Courier |accessdate =May 19, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110527154857/http://www.christiancourier.com/articles/582-harold-campings-new-revelation-leave-the-church| archivedate= May 27, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and drew "a flurry of attacks".<ref name = "CT" />
[[Edwin M. Yamauchi]] critiqued Camping's dating of the Flood when Camping first published his ideas in 1970.<ref name=BCH />
Criticism of the May 21 prediction ranged from serious critique to ridicule. Theology professor Matthew L. Skinner, writing at the [[Huffington Post]], noted the "long history of failed speculation" about the End Times and cautioned that end-of-the-world talk can lead Christians to social passivity instead of "working for the world's redemption".<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/matthew-l-skinner/apocalypse-now-or-later-o_b_839878.html |last = Skinner |first = Matthew L. |title = Apocalypse Now? A Christian Understanding of the End Times' |work=Huffington Post |date = March 27, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110511235856/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/matthew-l-skinner/apocalypse-now-or-later-o_b_839878.html| archivedate= May 11, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Some columnists mocked the prediction with humorous essays.<ref>{{cite news |title = Sinners, you have four days until Judgment Day. Are you prepared? |url = https://vancouversun.com/Sinners+have+four+days+until+Judgment+prepared/4795107/story.html |newspaper = Vancouver Sun |date = May 17, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520231628/http://www.vancouversun.com/Sinners+have+four+days+until+Judgment+prepared/4795107/story.html |archivedate=May 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ocregister.com/articles/camping-300947-things-saturday.html 10 unhealthy things to do before Armageddon] ''Orange County Register'', May 17, 2011. Retrieved May 18, 2011.</ref> A group of Christians set up a website called "RaptureFail" with the stated intention of undermining "this embarrassment to the Body of Christ."<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.rapturefail.org/about/ |title = About RaptureFail |date = May 21, 2011 |accessdate = May 23, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110523232243/http://www.rapturefail.org/about/ |archive-date = May 23, 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Evolutionary biologist and [[Atheism|atheist]] [[Richard Dawkins]] dismissed Camping's prediction, writing that "he will inevitably explain, on May 22, that there must have been some error in the calculation, the rapture is postponed to ... and please send more money to pay for updated billboards."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-faith/post/science-explains-the-end-of-the-world/2011/05/10/AFaLvBiG_blog.html "Science explains the end of the world"]. On Faith, ''Washington Post''. May 10, 2011. Retrieved May 11, 2011.</ref> California Director of [[American Atheists]] Larry Hicock said that "Camping's well-intentioned rapture campaign is indicative of the problems with religion".<ref name = "Hickock">{{cite web |first = RJ |last = Middleton |url = http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/weird/Oakland-Atheists-to-Counter-May-21-Doomsdayers-122041049.html |title = Atheists Offer Doomsdayers a Party |publisher = [[KNTV|NBC Bay Area]] |date = May 12, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref>
==Prediction for May 21, 2011==
===Information campaign=== [[File:2011-rapture-car.jpg|thumb|Vehicle in San Francisco proclaiming the Harold Camping prediction.]] In 2010, Marie Exley of [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] made news by purchasing advertising space in her locality, promoting the alleged Rapture date on a number of park benches.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.gazette.com/articles/unemployed-102074-springs-funded.html |title = Bus bench ads on Christ's return funded by unemployed Springs woman |location = 38.833882;-104.821363 |publisher = Colorado Springs Gazette |date = July 26, 2010 |accessdate =November 29, 2010}}</ref> After that, more than 3,000<ref>{{cite news |title=Group Claims World Will End May 21 |url=http://www.newsmax.com/US/FamilyRadio-HaroldCamping-Christianradio-Bible/2011/05/11/id/395988 |newspaper=NewsMax |date=May 11, 2011 |accessdate=May 30, 2011}}</ref> "Judgment Day" billboards were erected in locations across the world, including the [[Dominican Republic]], Ethiopia, [[Ghana]], [[Indonesia]], Israel, [[Jamaica]], Jordan, [[Lebanon]], [[Lesotho]], the [[Philippines]], [[Tanzania]] and the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/billboards/index.html |title = May 21, 2011 Judgment Day and Rapture Billboards |publisher = Ebiblefellowship.com |accessdate =November 29, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101031151242/http://ebiblefellowship.com/billboards/index.html| archivedate= October 31, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name= "msnbc22may">{{cite news |title = Believers' reactions mixed to unfulfilled doomsday |first = Garance |last = Burke |url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43126904/ns/us_news-life/ |newspaper = [[MSNBC]] |date = May 22, 2011 |accessdate =May 22, 2011}}</ref> Some people adorned their vehicles with the information.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/gallery/v/moving_billboards/ |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100115130623/http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/gallery/v/moving_billboards/ |dead-url = yes |archive-date = January 15, 2010 |title = Examples of "Moving Billboards" |publisher = Ebiblefellowship.com |accessdate = November 29, 2010 }}</ref> Many who believed in the prediction took time off work to prepare for the Rapture.<ref name="perplex">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13489641|title='Rapture': Believers perplexed after prediction fails|accessdate=May 22, 2011|work=BBC News|date=May 22, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110522111941/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13489641| archivedate= May 22, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Others spent their life savings on advertising material to publicise the prophecy.<ref name="perplex"/> One retired transportation agency worker from New York spent $140,000 on advertising.<ref name="perplex"/>
Family Radio spent over US$100 million on the information campaign, financed by sales and swap of broadcast outlets.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/la-me-rapture-20110521,0,1687317.story |title=Doomsday prediction: Harold Camping is at the heart of a mediapocalypse over his Doomsday prediction |last=Goffard |first=Christopher |date=May 21, 2011 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=May 23, 2011 |location=Oakland |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523052517/http://www.latimes.com/la-me-rapture-20110521%2C0%2C1687317.story |archivedate=May 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> On October 27, 2010, they launched "Project Caravan". Five [[recreational vehicle]]s announcing on their sides that Judgment Day was to begin on May 21, 2011 were sent out from their headquarters in [[Oakland, California]], to [[Seattle]], Washington. Upon arrival, teams were sent out to distribute [[Tract (literature)|tract]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.familyradio.com/english/connect/caravan/caravan_about.html |title = Project Caravan |publisher = Familyradio.com |accessdate = December 2, 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101113024538/http://familyradio.com/english/connect/caravan/caravan_about.html |archivedate = November 13, 2010 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref> The caravan subsequently made stops in many states in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.orovillemr.com/ci_16740516 |title = Entourage brings message of doom |publisher = Oroville Mercury-Register |date = November 30, 2010 |accessdate =December 2, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last = Gross |first = Daniel |title = Judgment Day caravan spreads message on campus |url = http://www.thetowerlight.com/2011/03/judgment-day-caravan-spreads-message-on-campus/comment-page-1/#comment-10113 |accessdate =March 28, 2011 |newspaper = The Towerlight |date = March 28, 2011}}</ref> and Canada.<ref>[http://www.globalsaskatoon.com/world+billboard+campaign+proclaims/4739175/story.html Postmedia News: "End of the world on May 21, billboard campaign proclaims", May 6, 2011.]</ref><ref>[http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/story.html?id=c1f8542e-4c51-4fd4-ae06-6d1a67740744&p=2 Calgary Herald: "Caravan of calamity heralds world's end", May 15, 2011.]</ref>
===Impact=== Camping's prediction and his promotion of it via his radio network and other promotional means spread the prediction globally,<ref name="party" /> which led believers and non-believers to a variety of actions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thedailymaverick.co.za/article/2010-08-16-may-21-2011-judgment-day-believers-descend-on-joburg |title = May 21, 2011: Judgment Day believers descend on Joburg |work = The Daily Maverick |accessdate =November 29, 2010}}</ref> Some followers of Camping gave up their jobs, sold their homes, stopped investing in their children's college funds and spent large sums promoting Camping's claims.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/rapture-prediction-to-devastate-christians-faith-50351/ |title = Rapture Prediction to Devastate Christians' Faith? |publisher = Christian Post |author = Stephanie Samuel |date = May 20, 2011 |series = Christian News |accessdate =May 23, 2011}}</ref>
About 5,000<ref name="party" /> ethnic [[Hmong people|Hmong]] gathered at a remote town in [[Vietnam]]'s [[Mường Nhé District]] in [[Điện Biên Province]] in early May, where they planned to await the arrival of Christ. The Vietnamese government broke up the gathering and arrested some people, describing them as "extremists".<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/vietnam-says-extremists-detained-after-hmong-gathering-area-still-off-limits-to-media/2011/05/12/AFo8KwxG_story.html |title = Vietnam says 'extremists' detained after Hmong gathering; area still off limits to media |work=The Washington Post |date = May 13, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011 }} {{Dead link|date=February 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Pastor Doan Trung Tin indicated that a translated version of Camping's prediction had influenced about 300 of his parishioners to go to the assembly point, selling their belongings to be able to afford the journey via bus.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_670405.html |title = Vietnam protesters lured by doomsday cult |work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref> Many of the Hmong Christians who escaped arrest were reportedly forced into hiding after the gathering.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_671077.html |title=Hundreds of Vietnam Hmong in hiding: Resident |date=May 21, 2011 |work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |accessdate=May 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525194535/http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_671077.html |archivedate=May 25, 2011 }}</ref>
On May 19, 2011, the search term "end of the world may 21st" reached second position on [[Google Trends]], based on the popularity of the search term in the United States. The related searches "Harold Camping", "May 21 doomsday", and "May 21 rapture" were also represented among the top 10 positions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.google.com/trends/hottrends?q=*&sa=X&date=2011-5-19 |title = Google Trends: end of the world May 21st |publisher=[[Google]] |date = May 19, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref> The [[New York Police Department]] stated: "We don't plan any additional coverage for the end of the world. Indeed, if it happens, fewer officers will be required for streets that presumably will be empty."<ref name="MyFoxNY">{{cite news |title = New Yorkers Weigh In on Pending 'Apocalypse' |url = http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/news/new-yorkers-weigh-in-on-pending-apocalypse-20110519 |date = May 19, 2011 |publisher = [[WNYW|MyFoxNY]] |accessdate =May 20, 2011}} – quote is on second video under the main one, approximately two-and-a-half minutes in.</ref>
===Reaction===
==== Reaction from Family Radio and Harold Camping ==== On the weekend of May 21–22, the Family Radio headquarters was closed with a paper note in the window stating, "This office is closed. Sorry we missed you!"<ref name="usa-today">''[[USA Today]]'' article: "[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2011/05/apocalypse-some-other-time/1?csp=hf Apocalypse some other time]."</ref> The Family Radio network remained on the air during May 21 and May 22, mostly broadcasting its normal schedule of programming, but with no mention of the Rapture and without the usual replays of Harold Camping's program ''Open Forum''.
On Sunday, May 22, Camping emerged briefly from his home, saying "Give me a day, no interviews today ... I've got to live with it, I've got to think it out."<ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/150201/20110523/harold-camping.htm Harold Camping found in Alameda <nowiki>[VIDEO]</nowiki>] – ''International Business Times''. May 22, 2011. Retrieved May 23, 2011.</ref> He said he would make a public statement on Monday, May 23.<ref name="NYT21May11">{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/22/us/22doomsday.html|title = Despite Careful Calculations, the World Does Not End|accessdate =May 22, 2011|last = McKinley|first = Jesse|date=May 2011|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/149971/20110523/exclusive-harold-camping-to-speak-monday-on-failed-prediction.htm EXCLUSIVE: Harold Camping to Speak Monday on Failed Prediction] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526214751/http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/149971/20110523/exclusive-harold-camping-to-speak-monday-on-failed-prediction.htm |date=May 26, 2011 }} – ''International Business Times''. May 22, 2011. Retrieved May 23, 2011.</ref> Camping said he was "flabbergasted" that the Rapture did not occur, that he was "looking for answers," and would say more when he returned to work on May 23.<ref>{{cite news|title=Harold Camping 'flabbergasted' world didn't end |last=Kane |first=Will |work=San Francisco Chronicle |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/05/22/BAKO1JJIK7.DTL&tsp=1 |date=May 22, 2011 |accessdate=May 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630074254/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2011%2F05%2F22%2FBAKO1JJIK7.DTL&tsp=1 |archivedate=June 30, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}.</ref>
On May 23, he returned to his ''Open Forum'' radio program, with members of the press in attendance, and, departing from his typical format, took questions from the reporters present instead of from callers.<ref name = "CP">[http://www.christianpost.com/news/harold-camping-concludes-silence-predicts-october-21-rapture-50438/ ''Harold Camping Concludes Silence, Predicts October 21 Rapture''] The Christian Post, May 23, 2011. Retrieved May 24, 2011</ref> He stated that May 21 had been an "invisible judgment day" which was purely spiritual in nature, and that he now realized that the physical Rapture would take place on October 21, simultaneously with the destruction of the universe. "We've always said May 21 was the day, but we didn't understand altogether the spiritual meaning," he said. "May 21 is the day that Christ came and put the world under judgment."<ref name = "G&M" /> He offered no apology for his earlier interpretation and said that all of his predictions had actually been fulfilled: on May 21, 1988, judgment came upon the churches; on September 7, 1994, judgment continued on the churches; then on May 21, 2011, judgment came upon the entire world.<ref name = "CP" />
He said that the publicity campaign would not continue, explaining that since God's judgment had already occurred, there was no point in continuing to warn people about it.<ref name="gazette" /> He added, "We're not going to put up any more billboards – in fact they're coming down right now."<ref>[http://gawker.com/5804846/rapture-predictor-harold-camping-apocalypse-rescheduled-to-october-21 Rapture Predictor Harold Camping: Apocalypse Rescheduled for October 21] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525234326/http://gawker.com/5804846/rapture-predictor-harold-camping-apocalypse-rescheduled-to-october-21 |date=May 25, 2011 }} Gawker, May 23, 2011. Retrieved May 26, 2011.</ref> Responding to a question, Camping said his organization would not return money donated by followers to publicize the May 21 prediction, saying "We're not at the end. Why would we return it?"<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/24/us/24rapture.html |work=The New York Times | date=May 23, 2011 | title=An Autumn Date for the Apocalypse |first=Jesse |last=McKinley}}</ref>
As October 21 approached, the Family Radio website stated: {{quote|What really happened (on May 21) is that God accomplished exactly what He wanted to happen. That was to warn the whole world that on May 21 God's salvation program would be finished on that day. For the next five months, except for the elect (the true believers), the whole world is under God's final judgment. To accomplish this goal God withheld from the true believers the way in which two phases were to be understood. Had He not done so, the world would never have been shaken in fear as it was.<ref>abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2011/10/harold-camping-predicts-end-of-the-world-again/</ref>}}
A Family Radio staffer suggested that the delay might be God's way of separating true believers from those willing to doubt the "clear biblical warnings."<ref name = "G&M" />
====Reaction from Harold Camping believers==== [[File:Judgment Day 21 May 2011 (Spanish).jpg|thumb|right|[[Family Radio]] sign in [[Denver]] predicting the end of the world in Spanish on May 21, 2011]] Individual followers who had spent time and money promoting Camping's prediction were "crestfallen" after May 21 passed without evidence of the Rapture. A New York man commented "I was doing what I've been instructed to do through the Bible, but now I've been stymied. It's like getting slapped in the face."<ref name="gazette">[http://www.gazette.com/articles/date-118626-world-host.html ''Radio host picks new date for world's end''] Associated Press, in Colorado Springs Gazette, May 24, 2011. Retrieved May 25, 2011</ref>
There were rumors that people had killed themselves or attempted suicide to escape the predicted Judgment Day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://lfpress.com/news/world/2011/05/12/18139906.html|title=Suicide pacts feared on May 21 'end'|last=Burnett|first=Thane|date=May 12, 2011|work=London Free Press|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref> There was one documented case, in which a 14-year-old Russian girl killed herself on May 21. Her family told a Russian tabloid, ''[[LifeNews]]'', that she did it because of her fear of the "terrible sufferings" predicted by Camping;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/fearful-teen-commits-suicide-on-eve-of-harold-campings-rapture-50542/|title=Fearful Teen Commits Suicide Due To Harold Camping's Judgment Day Prediction|last=Garcia|first=Elena|date=May 26, 2011|work=Christian Post|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref> however, police noted that the girl had been obsessed with death and threatening suicide since she was 12.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rt.com/news/teen-kills-rapture-predicted/|title=Teen kills herself ahead of foretold rapture|date=May 25, 2011|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT.com]]|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref>
====Reaction from other Christians==== A group of Christians in [[Milpitas, California]], offered a session to comfort those who had believed in the prophecy. Church deacon James Bynum told a local newspaper that "We are here because we care about these people. It's easy to mock them. But you can go kick puppies, too. But why?"<ref name="perplex"/>
====Reaction from non-believers and protesters==== In response to the prediction, more than 830,000 registered as attending a "Post Rapture Looting" event on Facebook.<ref name="facebook">Facebook group page: "[https://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=121968371215699 Post rapture looting]."</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43082513/ns/us_news-life/t/end-world-how-about-party-instead/|title=End of the world? How about a party instead?|last=Breen|first=Tom|date=May 18, 2011|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=May 30, 2011}}</ref> The group [[American Atheists]] sponsored billboards in several American cities declaring the Rapture to be "nonsense".<ref name = "Hickock" /> The group Seattle Atheists formed the Rapture Relief Fund which they said would be used "to help survivors of any Armageddon-sized disaster in the [[Puget Sound]] area";<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/atheists-offer-post-rapture-services-50278/ |title = Atheists Offer Post-Rapture Services |publisher = Christianpost.com |date = May 7, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref> since the Rapture failed to occur on May 21, the money will fund a camp that teaches children about science and critical thinking.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/komo/article/Seattle-Athiests-collect-for-Rapture-Relief-Fund-1382452.php |title = Seattle Atheists collect for "Rapture Relief Fund" |publisher = Seattle Post-Intelligencer |date = May 13, 2011 |accessdate =May 19, 2011}}</ref>
On May 21, groups of protesters gathered at Family Radio's headquarters in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] to mock the evangelical broadcaster's failed prediction. One group released human-shaped helium balloons to simulate souls rising to heaven,<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/8529127/Protesters-mock-end-of-world-church.html |title = Video: Protesters mock 'end of world' church |date = May 22, 2011 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate =May 23, 2011 |location=London}}</ref><ref>[http://pajamasmedia.com/zombie/2011/05/21/media-circus-of-biblical-proportions-at-armageddon-hq/ Pajamas Media: "Media Circus of Biblical Proportions at Armageddon HQ", May 21, 2011.]</ref> while another person played [[The Doors]]' song "[[The End (The Doors song)|The End]]" over a [[boombox]].<ref name="latimes-doors">''[[LA Times]]'' article: "[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-rapture-20110522,0,5118540.story In the end, rapture believers weren't going anywhere]."</ref> Many atheist and secular groups in the United States hosted "Rapture parties" on May 21.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13468131 |title = 'Rapture' apocalypse prediction sparks atheist reaction |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date = May 20, 2011 |accessdate =May 20, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520155338/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13468131| archivedate= May 20, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Other secular groups intentionally scheduled activities for Sunday, May 22, such as "Non-Judgmental Day", celebrating tolerance, cooperation and harmony.<ref>{{cite web|title=Non-Judgmental Day|publisher=Facebook event|url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=207910619243449#!/event.php?eid=207910619243449|accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref>
American Atheists hosted a two-day conference over the May 21 weekend in Oakland, not far from Camping's radio station. President David Silverman commented, "We're going to poke fun at these people, but in the end we need to keep in mind that there are people being hurt here ... We're hoping people look at this and learn to use their brains … so we don't have an occurrence of this in 2012" (when [[2012 phenomenon|some believed]] the [[Maya civilization|Mayans]] predicted as the Earth's final destruction).<ref>{{cite news|title=Harold Camping is at the heart of a mediapocalypse |url=http://www.latimes.com/la-me-rapture-20110521,0,1687317.story |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=May 21, 2011 |accessdate=May 30, 2011 |first=Christopher |last=Goffard |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523052517/http://www.latimes.com/la-me-rapture-20110521%2C0%2C1687317.story |archivedate=May 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Prediction for October 21, 2011== Camping continued to predict that October 21 would mark the end of the world, but modified his prediction with words like "probably" and "maybe". "I really am beginning to think as I've restudied these matters that there's going to be no big display of any kind," Camping said in a podcast. "The end is going to come very, very quietly."<ref>{{cite news |title=Harold Camping, rapture prophet, hedges new bet |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/20/BASV1LJD1N.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=October 20, 2011 |accessdate=October 21, 2011 |first=Justin |last=Berton}}</ref> He kept a low profile as the date approached, and his daughter responded to a media request by saying, "I'm sorry to disappoint you, but we at Family Radio have been directed to not talk to the media or the press."<ref>{{cite news |title=Harold Camping avoids press despite end-of-days prediction |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2011/1020/Harold-Camping-avoids-press-despite-end-of-days-prediction |newspaper=Christian Science Monitor |date=October 20, 2011 |accessdate=October 21, 2011}}</ref>
===Reaction===
No statement was issued by Camping or Family Radio on October 21 or 22.<ref name=WorldSurvives/><ref name = "Judgment Day doesn't dawn">{{cite web |url=http://www.news24.com/World/News/Judgment-Day-doesnt-dawn-20111021 |title=Judgment Day doesn't dawn |date=October 21, 2011 |publisher=news24 |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> It was later reported that Camping told an interviewer on October 16 that God has not given anyone the power to know exactly when the Rapture would come.<ref name = "retire" /> He retired from his leadership position at Family Radio.<ref name = "retire" /> Sometime after October 21, Family Radio posted an audio message from Harold Camping on their home page. In the message, Camping stated, regarding end times prophecy, that "we are finding it very very difficult". He also told followers to "not feel abandoned by God" and that "God is still in charge of everything".
As October 21 approached, the [[Freedom from Religion Foundation]] bought space on more than 40 billboards in the Bay Area to mock Camping's predictions and urge viewers to use rational judgment. The billboards featured slogans such as, "Fool me once...", "Still here", and "Every day is judgment day. Use yours. Use reason."<ref>[http://ffrf.org/news/releases/ffrfs-fool-me-once-campaign-asks-onlookers-to-judge-religion/ Freedom from Religion Foundation website]</ref>
Media reports on October 21 and 22 stressed that Camping had been "wrong again".<ref>{{cite news |title=Harold Camping: Doomsday Prophet Wrong Again |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/business/2011/10/harold-camping-doomsday-prophet-wrong-again/ |newspaper=ABC News |date=October 22, 2011 |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Harold Camping Doomsday Wrong Again; Now on to December 2012? |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/harold-camping-doomsday-wrong-again-now-on-to-december-2012-59033/ |newspaper=Christian Post |date=October 22, 2011 |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> The ''[[International Business Times]]'' proclaimed him a "false prophet."<ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/149632/20110521/harold-camping-false-prophet-ministry-probably-doomed.htm Harold Camping False Prophet: Ministry Probably Doomed], ''International Business Times'', October 21, 2011</ref> On October 21, 2011, ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' magazine's website listed Camping's end times predictions as one of the "Top 10 Failed Predictions", a list compiled in Camping's "honor".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2097462_2097456_2097489,00.html | title=Top 10 Failed Predictions |work=Time | date=October 21, 2011 | accessdate=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
== Personal developments == Family Radio removed from its web site the archive of audio recordings of Camping's Open Forum program recorded prior to May 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fsiarchive1.familyradio.org/forum/mp3d.php |title=Open Forum Download Archive |access-date=July 25, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728174447/http://fsiarchive1.familyradio.org/forum/mp3d.php |archive-date=July 28, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On June 9, 2011, Camping suffered a stroke and was hospitalized.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harold Camping Hospitalized by Stroke; Speech Affected |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/harold-camping-of-family-radio-suffers-stroke-speech-affected-51102/ |newspaper=The Christian Post |date=June 12, 2011 |accessdate=August 22, 2011}}</ref> Family Radio broadcast reruns of his May 23 – June 9 Open Forum segments for several weeks. As of June 23 Family Radio began to provide new programming in his time slot.<ref>{{cite news|title=Doomsday herald Harold Camping's show goes off the air at the end of the month |url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_18331982 |newspaper=Oakland Tribune |date=June 23, 2011 |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710030937/http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_18331982 |archivedate=July 10, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Camping died on December 15, 2013 at the age of 92, as a result of complications from a fall at home two weeks earlier.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/doomsday-minister-harold-camping-dead-92-21248011| title=Doomsday Minister Harold Camping Dead at 92| date=December 17, 2013| agency=Associated Press| publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=T. Rees Shapiro |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/harold-camping-radio-evangelist-who-predicted-doomsday-dies-at-92/2012/05/16/gJQAlgpxAp_story.html |title=Harold Camping, radio evangelist who predicted 2011 doomsday, dies at 92 |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2013-12-13 |accessdate=2013-12-18}}</ref>

(2009)<ref>{{cite web|title=No Man Knows the Day or the Hour?|url=http://worldwide.familyradio.org/en/graphical/literature/nomanknows/nomanknows.html|publisher=Family Stations Inc.|access-date=July 22, 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130414214746/http://worldwide.familyradio.org/en/graphical/literature/nomanknows/nomanknows.html|archive-date=April 14, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
== Other ministries or organizations that taught the 2011 end times prediction == {{primary sources|section|date=August 2012}}
===eBible Fellowship=== Owned and operated by Chris McCann.<ref>{{cite web|title=eBible Fellowship|url=http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/}}</ref> Publications include: * ''The End of the World October 21, 2011''<ref>{{cite book|title=The End of the World October 21, 2011|publisher=eBible Fellowship|url=http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/generated/outreach/tracts/may21/}}</ref> * ''The Bible Reveals WE CAN KNOW May 21, 2011 is Judgment Day!''<ref>{{cite book|title=The Bible Reveals WE CAN KNOW May 21, 2011 is Judgment Day!|publisher=eBible Fellowship|url=http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/outreach/tracts/wecanknow/index.html}}</ref>
McCann continued to teach that October 21, 2011 would be the end of the world, even after the failed May 21, 2011 prediction. And after October 21, 2011, he taught that the end of the world would occur in March 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Link Between May 21, 2011 and the Feast of Purim in March 2012|url=http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/2012-end-of-the-world/|publisher=eBible Fellowship}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Video: The Link Between May 21, 2011 and the Feast of Purim in March 2012|url=http://vimeo.com/36590434|publisher=eBible Fellowship}}.</ref>
At the end of 2012, McCann began teaching the possibility that the last day would be October 7, 2015.<ref>{{cite news |title=Apocalypse Shortly?|url=http://articles.philly.com/2013-05-29/news/39582351_1_harold-camping-ebible-fellowship-judgment-day| newspaper=Philadelphia Weekly |date=May 29, 2013 |accessdate=February 1, 2014}}</ref> He said that there was "a strong likelihood that this will happen" and "an unlikely possibility that it will not".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/06/end-of-world-7-october-ebible-fellowship The Guardian newspaper:Christian group predicts the world will be 'annihilated' on Wednesday, 6 October 2015]</ref>
This date was arrived at by adding 1600 days (taken from {{Bibleverse||Revelation|14:20|KJV}}) to May 21, 2011, which McCann still teaches is the beginning of the day of judgment. He noted that October 7, 2015 is last day of the [[Feast of Tabernacles]], and exactly 10,000 days from May 21, 1988, which he claims is the date the Church Age came to an end.<ref>{{cite web|title=Can 1600 Furlongs Represent 1600 Days? |url=http://www.ebiblefellowship.com/archives/2012/12/26/can-1600-furlongs-represent-1600-days/|publisher=eBible Fellowship}}</ref>

{{For|the novel|Abattoir Blues (novel)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox album | name = Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus | type = studio | artist = [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]] | cover = Abattoir Blues+The Lyre of Orpheus.jpg | alt = A photograph of a series of flowers in part of an arc are surrounded by a cream coloured border. Black text above the photograph reads "Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds" and italicised black text reads "Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus". | released = {{Start date|2004|09|20|df=yes}} | recorded = March–April 2004 | venue = | studio = Studio Ferber in [[Paris]], France | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative rock]]|[[gothic rock]]}} | length = {{Duration|m=82|s=30}} | label = [[Mute Records|Mute]] | producer = [[Nick Launay]] | prev_title = [[Nocturama (album)|Nocturama]] | prev_year = 2003 | next_title = [[B-Sides & Rarities (Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds album)|B-Sides & Rarities]] | next_year = 2005 | misc = {{Singles | name = Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus | type = studio | single1 = Nature Boy | single1date = 6 September 2004 | single2 = Breathless / There She Goes, My Beautiful World | single2date = 15 November 2004 | single3 = Get Ready for Love | single3date = 14 March 2005 }} }} '''''Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus''''' is the thirteenth studio album by the Australian [[alternative rock]] band [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]], released on 20 September 2004 on [[Mute Records]]. It is a [[double album]] with a total of seventeen songs—nine on ''Abattoir Blues'' and eight on ''The Lyre of Orpheus''. ==History== The album was produced by [[Nick Launay]] at Studio Ferber in Paris in March–April 2004 and [[Nick Cave]] used The Bad Seeds line up of [[Mick Harvey]], [[Thomas Wydler]], [[Martyn Casey]], [[Conway Savage]], [[Jim Sclavunos]], [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]], and [[James Johnston (English musician)|James Johnston]]. It was the first album by the group for which [[Blixa Bargeld]] did not perform – English guitarist and organist Johnston, of the group [[Gallon Drunk]], replaced Bargeld. Cave decided to split drumming duties for the two parts, with Sclavunos on ''Abattoir Blues'' and Wydler on ''The Lyre of Orpheus''. According to Launay, the whole album was completed in twelve days.[http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_Nick_Launay_Interview.html "Interview With Nick Launay"], ''[[HitQuarters]]'', 16 November 2009. The album's release was supported by the Abattoir Blues Tour, which travelled through Europe from 2 November to 5 December. In January 2007 a double live album and DVD was issued as ''[[The Abattoir Blues Tour]]''. ''Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus''{{'}}s last track, "O Children", was featured in the 2010 film ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1]]'', and the song is referenced as an achievement in ''[[Lego Harry Potter: Years 5–7]]''. In March 2005, to complement the success of the double album, Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds released ''[[B-Sides & Rarities (Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds album)|B-Sides & Rarities]]'', a three-disc, 56-track collection of [[A-side and B-side|B-side]]s, rarities, and tracks that had appeared on film soundtracks. ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings | MC = 88/100{{cite web [[Susan Carpenter]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described the album as "a bounty of [[gothic rock]]" and noted that "the more driving, menacing numbers have been separated from the slow and scurrilous in a double album that is not two halves of a whole so much as two distinct records released simultaneously and in one package."{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/oct/28/news/wk-pop28 |title=A fertile mind for dark tales |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=28 October 2004 |accessdate=2 January 2012 |last=Carpenter |first=Susan |authorlink=Susan Carpenter}} Thom Jurek of [[AllMusic]] described ''Abattoir Blues'' as "a [[rock and roll|rock & roll]] record... a pathos-drenched, volume-cranked rocker, full of crunch, punishment – and taste" and ''The Lyre of Orpheus'' as "a much quieter, more elegant affair... more consciously restrained, its attention to craft and theatrical flair more prevalent.". Greg Simpson of Punknews.org said that ''Abattoir Blues'' "is very bluesy indeed, a rock and roll album with many angry songs and booming bass lines," while ''The Lyre of Orpheus'' "insists on being a separate album, due to its completely different more gentle feel."{{cite web |url=http://www.punknews.org/review/3421/nick-cave-and-the-bad-seeds-abattoir-blues-the-lyre-of-orpheus |title=Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds – Abattoir Blues / The Lyre Of Orpheus |publisher=Punknews.org |date=29 October 2004 |accessdate=27 February 2013 |author=greg0rb}} In a rave review, ''[[Tiny Mix Tapes]]'' critic Grigsby wrote that while ''Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus'' "may not be the best beginner's guide" to the band, for "anyone who is a fan of the duration of his career, this album rewards the listener with a bit of the best of everything he has to offer."{{cite web |url=http://www.tinymixtapes.com/music-review/nick-cave-abattoir-bluesthe-lyre-orpheus-bad-seeds |title=Nick Cave – Abattoir Blues/The Lyre of Orpheus (& The Bad Seeds) |work=[[Tiny Mix Tapes]] |accessdate=27 February 2013 |author=Grigsby}} ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' said: "Aside from the power of the music and lyrics, the set draws on Cave’s compelling persona: part priest, part sideshow barker--crooning one moment and eviscerating the next. While this has always been the core of his talent, on ''Abattoir/Lyre'' it is particularly rich and rewarding."{{cite journal |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2004/10/nick-cave-the-bad-seeds.html |title=Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds: Abattoir Blues/The Lyre of Orpheus |work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |date=1 October 2004 |accessdate=27 February 2013 |last=Sheridan |first=Tim}} In a more mixed assessment, [[Douglas Wolk]], writing in ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'', was complimentary of ''Abattoir Blues'' but felt that ''The Lyre of Orpheus'' was "effectively ''Abattoir'' spillover: more mellow, less grand in conception, but—somehow—more pretentious in execution." In his Consumer Guide for ''[[The Village Voice]]'', [[Robert Christgau]] designated three songs from the album ("The Lyre of Orpheus", "There She Goes, My Beautiful World", and "Hiding All Away") as "choice cuts",{{cite news |url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cg/cgv205-05.php |title=Consumer Guide: Harmonies and Abysses |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=8 February 2005 |accessdate=31 October 2015 |last=Christgau |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Christgau}} indicating good songs "on an album that isn't worth your time or money."{{cite web |url=http://robertchristgau.com/xg/bk-cg90/grades-90s.php |title=Key to Icons |publisher=RobertChristgau.com |accessdate=31 October 2015 |last=Christgau |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Christgau}} The music [[online magazine]] [[Pitchfork Media]] placed ''Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus'' at number 180 on their list of top 200 albums of the 2000s.{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/features/staff-lists/7706-the-top-200-albums-of-the-2000s-200-151/3/ |work=[[Pitchfork Media]] |author=Pitchfork staff |title=The Top 200 Albums of the 2000s: 200-151|date=28 September 2009 |accessdate=1 October 2009}} The album was also included in the book ''[[1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die]]''.{{cite book|author1=Robert Dimery|author2=Michael Lydon|title=1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die: Revised and Updated Edition|accessdate= |date=23 March 2010|publisher=Universe|isbn=978-0-7893-2074-2}} ==Charts== It peaked at No. 5 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]], its chart success in Europe includes No. 1 in Norway, No. 2 in Austria and Denmark, and top 10 in Belgium, Finland, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, and Sweden.{{cite web | url = http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Nick+Cave+%26+The+Bad+Seeds&titel=Abattoir+Blues+%2F+The+Lyre+Of+Orpheus&cat=a | title = Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds – ''Abattoir Blues / The Lyre of Orpheus'' | publisher = Australian Charts Portal. Hung Medien | accessdate =29 September 2011 }} The album reached No. 1 on the [[IFPI Greece|Foreign Albums Chart]] in Greece where it also received a [[List of music recording certifications|gold]] certification.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.gr/chart01.htm |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2005-02-04 |accessdate=2012-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050204045617/http://www.ifpi.gr/chart01.htm |archivedate=4 February 2005 }} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Disc one: ''Abattoir Blues'' | total_length = 43:05 | all_writing = [[Nick Cave]] unless otherwise noted | title1 = Get Ready for Love | writer1 = [[Nick Cave]], [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]], [[Martyn P. In '''Judaism''', there is debate but not accepted evidence that cannabis may have been used ritually in ancient Judaism, and the use of cannabis continues to be a controversial topic in modern Judaism.
==Theories on ancient use== It is generally held by academics specializing in the archaeology and paleobotany of [[Ancient Israel]], and those specializing in the lexicography of the [[Hebrew Bible]] that cannabis is not documented or mentioned in early Judaism. Against this some popular writers<ref>Dan Merkur ''The Mystery of Manna: The Psychedelic Sacrament of the Bible'' (2001); James D. Dure, ''Manna Magic Mushroom of Moses : Manna Botanical I.D. of a Biblical Sacrament'' (self published, 2000)</ref> have argued that there is evidence for religious use of cannabis in the Hebrew Bible, although this hypothesis and some of the specific case studies (e.g., [[John Allegro]] in relation to [[Qumran]], 1970) have been "widely dismissed as erroneous" (Merlin, 2003).<ref>[[Economic Botany]] [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1663/0013-0001(2003)057%5B0295:AEFTTO%5D2.0.CO%3B2#page-1 M. D. Merlin Archaeological Evidence for the Tradition of Psychoactive Plant Use in the Old World - University of Hawaii] "23 May 2011 - ".. Judaism (Dure 2001; Merkur 2000), and Christianity (Allegro 1970; Ruck et al. 2001). Although this hypothesis and some of the specific case studies (e.g., Allegro 1970) have been widely dismissed as erroneous, others continue"</ref> The primary advocate of a religious use of cannabis plant in early Judaism was [[Sula Benet]] (1967), who claimed that the plant ''kaneh bosm קְנֵה-בֹשֶׂם'' mentioned five times in the Hebrew Bible, and used in the [[holy anointing oil]] of the Book of Exodus, was in fact cannabis,<ref>Rowan Robinson, The Great Book of Hemp, Health & Fitness, 1995, pag. 89</ref> although lexicons of Hebrew and dictionaries of plants of the Bible such as by [[Michael Zohary]] (1985), [[Hans Arne Jensen]] (2004) and [[James A. Duke]] (2010) and others identify the plant in question as either ''[[Acorus calamus]]'' or ''[[Cymbopogon citratus]]''.<ref>Lytton J. Musselman ''Figs, dates, laurel, and myrrh: plants of the Bible and the Quran'' 2007 p73</ref>
According to those theories that hold that cannabis was present in Ancient Israelite society, a variant of [[hashish]] is held to have been present.<ref>Warf, Barney. "High points: An historical geography of cannabis." Geographical Review 104.4 (2014): 414-438. Page 422: "Psychoactive cannabis is mentioned in the Talmud, and the ancient Jews may have used hashish (Clarke and Merlin 2013)."</ref>
==Modern era== {{see also|Cannabis in Israel}} In the United States, the Jewish population is overrepresented among the recreational cannabis using population. The reasons for this are thought to be their urban pattern of residence, the disproportionate association of Jewish residents in the academic milieu of the city as well as its avant-garde moments, and that Jewish families are thought to be less authoritarian and more tolerant toward "intellectual experimentation". In Toronto, differences between Jews and Christians with regard to attitudes toward cannabis usage were detected in the high school population, in which surveys show that more than twice as many Jewish students have used cannabis as Catholic ones.<ref name=Goode>{{cite book |last1=Goode |first1=Erich |title=Between Politics and Reason |isbn=0-312-13297-2 |url=http://druglibrary.net/special/goode/mjsmokers2.htm |chapter=Chapter 2 — A Profile of the Marijuana Smoker |quote=...Jews are far more likely to smoke marijuana than Gentiles, at least among young adults... Although it is possible that this over-representation can be entirely explained by Jewish dominance in academic and quasi-academic milieu in New York City (the groups to which I had readiest access), there are indications that lead me to suspect that there are social and cultural factors linking the Jews to activities such as marijuana use... Many of the avant-garde political and artistic movements today are associated with marijuana smoking, and the Jews are strongly over-represented in these movements... But it is to say that Jews will be more likely to be found among the more progressive artists and writers, and among the more radical and revolutionary political activists in America today. And it is precisely the political and artistic avant-garde that is most likely to smoke marijuana. However, we need not even concern ourselves with society's most progressive and revolutionary members, since they form such a tiny percentage of any population. Even contrasting Jews in general ( not merely the most liberal among them) with Gentiles in general, it is clear that in many ways, Jews grow up in … a family ambiance with a lower level of authoritarianism, greater tolerance, and a respect for intellectual experimentation. (The Jewish family is, however, much more rigid in many other ways, such as the closeness of family ties.)… Whatever the reasons, Jewish youths do seem to experiment with drugs, particularly marijuana, more than Gentiles. A study was done by the Toronto Addiction Research Foundation, entitled A Preliminary Report on the Attitudes and Behaviour of Toronto Students in Relation to Drugs. Of the Catholic high school students, 7 percent had taken drugs (mainly marijuana), and 75 percent said that they would not take drugs. These figures were g percent and 74 percent for Protestants. Among the Jewish students, about 15 percent had taken drugs, and 64 percent said that they would not use them...}}</ref>
In a 1973 opinion, Orthodox rabbi [[Moshe Feinstein]] stated that cannabis was not permitted under Jewish law, due to its harmful effects.<ref name="Jacobs1993">{{cite book|author=Julian G. Jacobs|title=Judaism looks at modern issues|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mVIRAQAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Aviva Press|isbn=978-0-9511560-2-5}}</ref><ref name="Earleywine2007">{{cite book|author=Mitch Earleywine|title=Pot Politics: Marijuana and the Costs of Prohibition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fgASDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA218|year=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-518802-8|pages=218–}}</ref><ref name="Rosner2001">{{cite book|author=Fred Rosner|title=Biomedical Ethics and Jewish Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T7w2oAmohpEC&pg=PA92|year=2001|publisher=KTAV Publishing House, Inc.|isbn=978-0-88125-701-4|pages=92–}}</ref>
In 2013, Orthodox rabbi [[Efraim Zalmanovich]] stated that medical, but not recreational, cannabis is kosher. In 2016, Belarusian-Israeli rabbi [[Chaim Kanievsky]] declared that medicinal cannabis was [[kosher for Passover]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Elsa Vulliamy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/marijuana-is-kosher-for-passover-leading-rabbi-rules-a6995761.html |title=Marijuana is kosher for Passover, leading rabbi rules |publisher=The Independent |date=2016-04-22 |accessdate=2017-02-13}}</ref> In January 2016, the [[Orthodox Union]] certified some medical cannabis products made by [[Vireo]] as kosher, their first medical cannabis certification.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/07/business/kosher-medical-marijuana-heads-to-market.html|title=The Rabbis Are Here to Inspect the (Legal) Weed|first=Rachel|last=Abrams|date=6 May 2016|publisher=|via=New York Times}}</ref>
In the United States, the Jewish Social Policy Action Network in Philadelphia and Rabbi Eric Cytrin of Temple Beth El in Harrisburg, have supported medical legalization efforts for [[cannabis in Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thejewishchronicle.net/view/full_story/23157425/article-Kosher-for-pain-relief?|title=Kosher for pain relief|publisher=Jewish Chronicle}}</ref>
==Kashrut== If smoked, under normal circumstances there is no reason cannabis would not be kosher, although some rabbis apply this only to medical cannabis, not recreational usage.<ref name=IfYouEatIt>{{cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/jewish/kosher-washing-medical-marijuana-1.5387374|title=Marijuana is Always Kosher, if you smoke it|agency=Haaretz}}</ref> However, this is excepting that smoking it typically involves lighting a spark, so it would not be appropriate for example after sundown on [[Shabbat]]. If cannabis is "eaten", as edibles are, on the other hand, the issue is not as clear cut, as there may be small insects inside which are not kosher. For the observant it is recommended to only use brands that are certified as kosher.<ref name=IfYouEatIt/> For cannabis grown in Israel, the plants must observe [[Shmittah]], but this does not apply to cannabis from elsewhere.<ref name=IfYouEatIt/>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Cannabis and Judaism}}
